docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTORS routinely advise women to refrain from sexual activity for several weeks after childbirth, and for most women postpartum pain and exhaustion are incentives enough to comply. But for those who do not follow doctors' orders, the consequences can be serious and, in rare cases, even fatal. In the current issue of The Postgraduate Medical Journal, a publication of the British Medical Association, doctors describe two young women who died while having intercourse within eight days of giving birth. Both had had normal vaginal deliveries and died of air embolisms, air bubbles in the major arteries to the heart and brain.

headline.main: Deaths Linked to Sex After Childbirth

docs.abstract: Doctors' warning that women should refrain from sexual activity for several weeks after childbirth gets support in report in British Medical Assn publication in which doctors describe two young women who died while having intercourse within eight days of giving birth; both had normal vaginal deliveries and died of air embolisms, air bubbles in major arteries to heart and brain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Wednesday about a woman who is suing Lenox Hill Hospital over the results of an amniocentesis test misstated the date that the woman, Janet Shei khan, and her husband, Mohammad, were photographed. It was Sept. 16, not last Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the start of the 90's, when employers' health insurance costs were surging 15 percent a year, the giant Sprint Corporation was quick to shift to health maintenance organizations and their businesslike management of medical care. Sprint's costs promptly stabilized. Today, its comprehensive benefit program stands as a model of what Congress and industry envisioned four years ago when they rejected President Clinton's health plan and left the health care system to the tides of the marketplace.

headline.main: Reality of the H.M.O. System Doesn't Live Up to the Dream

docs.abstract: Article in ongoing series, After the Revolution, on effect of managed care on nation's health care system; even though managed care plans are entrenched in economy, enrolling 61 percent of population, they have lost luster as industry and as answer to nation's health care needs; while they have provided different way to pay for medical care, they have not offered better way to provide it; even though savings to large employers have been real, contributing significantly to current economic boom, they are likely to prove temporary since coverage has become more expensive for small businesses and self-employed and has shifted many consumers' concerns from cost to quality; recent New York Times poll finds 85 percent of Americans believe health care system needs fundamental change, compared with 90 percent in 1994 before Clinton Administration's health-reform plan died, and that although 68 percent say they are satisfied with quality of family's health care, 30 percent say they are not--up from 19 percent in 1994; percentage dissatisfied with cost of health care is practically unchanged at 46 percent; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Slices of afternoon sun cut through the blinds of a darkened second-floor room in the Hollywood Athletic Club as Joni Mitchell, cigarette hanging limply from her thick lips, bends over a pool table and meticulously lines up a shot to sink the solid yellow ball. ''You're stripes,'' one of her pool partners yells.

headline.main: The Hissing of a Living Legend

docs.abstract: Neil Strauss profiles singer/songwriter and folk music legend Joni Mitchell; photos (L)
